unnormalised: Someone asked me about the proper way to address folks in India, especially when you're not sure of their background. It's a minefield, I tell you! Early on, when I moved to Mumbai, I addressed a lady at the bank as "Ms. Sharma." She politely corrected me, saying, "It's Mrs., actually, but 'ji' is fine." That’s when I learnt a valuable lesson about titles and respect here.

That is when I learnt a valuable lesson about titles and respect here.

unnormalised: In general, "ji" is your safest bet. Add it to the end of a name – Sharma ji, Khan ji, Iyer ji – and you’re golden. It's respectful without being overly formal. For older men, "Uncle" or "Chacha" (if they are Hindu) or "Uncle" and "chacha" or "janaab" (if they are Muslim) works well if you are familiar and if appropriate. For older women, "Aunty" or "Chachi" (if they are Hindu) or "Aunty" or "Khala" (if they are Muslim) works. If you know someone is a "Dr.", "Er.", "Adv." or "Prof.", use it! I mean, Dr. Patel deserves the respect after all those years in med school. Be aware, though, that people using "Kumar" "Verma" or "Singh" as last names can be either Sikh or Hindu.

unnormalised: Ultimately, observe and listen. Pay attention to how others address them, and follow suit. Asking is always okay too; a simple, "How would you prefer to be addressed?" goes a long way. The most important thing is showing respect and courtesy, and usually, a smile and a 'ji' will get you everywhere. Just remember that time I called the CEO "Bhaiya" because I thought he was the tea-wallah. *facepalm* Don't be like me.
